factoid: Natásha says that not everyone will understand the friendship dating from the addressee's childish days.
Natásha says that seeing Nicholas so intimate with the addressee may injure the addressee in the eyes of other young men who visit them.
Natásha says that it torments Nicholas for nothing.
Natásha says that Nicholas may already have found a suitable and wealthy match.
Natásha says that Nicholas is now half crazy.

Natásha hums a scrap from her favorite opera by Cherubini.
Natásha calls Dunyásha the maid to put out the candle.
Natásha had already passed into another happier world of dreams before Dunyásha left.
The countess called Borís aside and had a talk with him.
After the talk, Borís ceased coming to the Rostóvs'.
On the thirty-first of December, New Year’s Eve, 1809-10, an old grandee of Catherine’s day was giving a ball and midnight supper.
The diplomatic corps and the Emperor himself were to be present.
